April 20, 1967
The Honorable Quentin N. Burdick
Senate of the united States
Washington, D.C.
Dear Sirs
This is in response to your kind letter informing me
of your support for the Public Television Act of 1967 (8. 1160)*
Z speak for my colleagues at the University of North Dakota
Broadcasting Service as well as myself in expressing deep
appreciation for your positive position. Your statement before
the Communications Subcommittee on April 13, 1967, was pro¬
foundly encouraging to all of us. We especially appreciated
your citing our music program distributed throughout the state.
Your views of the broad definition for the term
EducationalM in reference to use of the broadcast media seemed
especially appropriate. Your final paragraph regarding equitable
distribution of funds was an excellent recommendation, and if
adopted, should assist greatly in the development of smaller
installations like ourselves.
You may be interested in learning of indications that
to the extent that the leadership prevails of the National
Association of Broadcasters (NAB), the commercial broadcasting
industry will be cautious but generally supportive of the
legislation for public television and radio. This is very
encouraging to us.
May I draw your attention to the title of S. 11607 As
the title now reads, it omits recognition of radio. It would
seem more appropriate if the modification read, NFublic Broad¬
casting Act of 1967*♦ Such a change would reconcile the title
more appropriately to the inclusion of radio in the substance
of the act.
